caption_original: We’re proud to announce the establishment of 7 new marine refuges off the coasts of Nunavut and Newfoundland and Labrador. These sites will provide protection to bottom-dwelling species such as corals, sponges, and Atlantic cod, and habitats important for spawning, breeding, and feeding for many aquatic species ow.ly/SzMg100TzFZ
caption_cleaned: We’re proud to announce the establishment of new marine refuges off the coasts of Nunavut and Newfoundland and Labrador. These sites will provide protection to bottom-dwelling species such as corals, sponges, and Atlantic cod, and habitats important for spawning, breeding, and feeding for many aquatic species

caption_original: We’re taking steps to protect the habitat of eight aquatic species. Today, Minister LeBlanc announced the signing of Critical Habitat Orders to ensure the important habitats of aquatic species are protected against destruction. This includes protections for North Atlantic Right Whale habitat in the Grand Manan Basin (Bay of Fundy, New Brunswick) and the Roseway Basin (off Southwestern Nova Scotia), and for the St. Lawrence Estuary Beluga. http://ow.ly/9VwD30hd0xL
caption_cleaned: We’re taking steps to protect the habitat of eight aquatic species. Today, Minister LeBlanc announced the signing of Critical Habitat Orders to ensure the important habitats of aquatic species are protected against destruction. This includes protections for North Atlantic Right Whale habitat in the Grand Manan Basin (Bay of Fundy, New Brunswick) and the Roseway Basin (off Southwestern Nova Scotia), and for the St. Lawrence Estuary Beluga.

caption_original:
Parks Canada announced today that Hecate Strait and Queen Charlotte Sound Glass Sponge Reefs Marine Protected Area has been nominated to be considered for inclusion to UNESCO’s World Heritage List! 
These glass sponges are globally unique to Canada’s West Coast and were once thought to be extinct worldwide.  Learn more about these delicate and ancient species: http://ow.ly/JyAs30hm7oM

caption_original: This summer, several of our researchers participated in a nearshore fish survey in Darnley Bay in the Northwest Territories, where they captured footage of some beautiful animals that call the Anguniaqvia niqiqyuam Marine Protected Area (MPA) home. This is the first MPA with conservation objectives based on Indigenous and traditional knowledge. http://ow.ly/DBD730hnLXO

caption_original: We’re proud to introduce a new program designed to help small and medium-sized businesses access clean technology that reduces environmental emissions—the Fisheries and Aquaculture Clean Technology Adoption Program. Clean technologies help us protect Canada’s natural environment by reducing the impact of day-to-day fishing and aquaculture activities. We’re providing up to $20 million over four years to help sectors access clean technologies that reduce their environmental impact through improved processes, products and services. http://ow.ly/ij8D30hiiQQ
caption_cleaned: We’re proud to introduce a new program designed to help small and medium-sized businesses access clean technology that reduces environmental emissions—the Fisheries and Aquaculture Clean Technology Adoption Program. Clean technologies help us protect Canada’s natural environment by reducing the impact of day-to-day fishing and aquaculture activities. We’re providing up to $20 million over four years to help sectors access clean technologies that reduce their environmental impact through improved processes, products and services.

caption_original:
Who doesn’t want glowing skin for the holidays? Check out these bowhead whales rubbing themselves on rocks to remove old skin off of Baffin Island in Nunavut. Aerial drones and our scientists caught rare footage that had never before been filmed from the air! 

Thanks to our partners for making this project possible: WWF-Canada, LGL Limited, VDOS Global LLC, University of British Columbia  Higdon Wildlife Consulting, Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution (WHOI), Pangnirtung Hunter and Trappers Association and Peter's Expediting & Outfitting Services. 

Video credit:  VDOS Global LLC

caption_original: The Round Goby is a small, bottom-dwelling invasive fish that has unfortunately spread through all five Great Lakes in less than a decade. To prevent the spread of this invasive species, never buy or use Round Goby as bait, and never live transfer bait between waterbodies, which are against the law. They prefer waters with rocky and sandy bottoms, and feed aggressively on insects, molluscs, and other small organisms. They have even been known to eat juvenile freshwater mussels, many of which are at-risk! Round Goby are also found in some inland waters in southern Ontario such as Lake Simcoe, the Trent River, Rice Lake, and parts of the Otonabee River. To report sightings, please visit http://ow.ly/VBIh30gZZE2

caption_original:
We have an app for that! In collaboration with The Toronto Zoo, we developed a free mussel app called “Clam Counter”. The app has information about all of Canada’s mussel species, a number of which are considered species at risk. You can learn information to help identify mussels, or simply get a list of species that can be found in a lake or river nearby. You can even report a mussel finding to help discover and protect our mussels! Download the app here:
Apple: http://ow.ly/XXZh30hoKBo
Android: http://ow.ly/KsVJ30hoKFX

caption_original: It’s Arctic Science Month! This past summer, an underwater cable system was laid in part of the Northwest Passage to help scientists measure ice thickness, water temperature, passive acoustics & much more. The 8-km cable connects to an on-shore computer that communicates directly to the Bedford Institute of Oceanography in Dartmouth, Nova Scotia. This system helps to collect important data in real-time, even when the ice is 4m thick! http://ow.ly/QX4V30hnL1f
caption_cleaned: It’s Arctic Science Month! This past summer, an underwater cable system was laid in part of the Northwest Passage to help scientists measure ice thickness, water temperature, passive acoustics & much more. The -km cable connects to an on-shore computer that communicates directly to the Bedford Institute of Oceanography in Dartmouth, Nova Scotia. This system helps to collect important data in real-time, even when the ice is m thick!

caption_original: Our scientists in Newfoundland and Labrador are improving the accuracy of weather and climate forecasts for all Canadians through important contributions to ocean forecasting systems. Over the past two years, researchers like Fraser Davidson have deployed 50 oceanographic ‘drifters’ to collect hourly data on temperature and air pressure on the Newfoundland and Labrador Shelves. This data allows us to work with Environment and Climate Change Canada to evaluate and improve marine weather forecasting systems. This map shows a day’s estimated currents with tracks of all drifters deployed in the area over the last 18 months. http://navigator.oceansdata.ca/
caption_cleaned: Our scientists in Newfoundland and Labrador are improving the accuracy of weather and climate forecasts for all Canadians through important contributions to ocean forecasting systems. Over the past two years, researchers like Fraser Davidson have deployed oceanographic ‘drifters’ to collect hourly data on temperature and air pressure on the Newfoundland and Labrador Shelves. This data allows us to work with Environment and Climate Change Canada to evaluate and improve marine weather forecasting systems. This map shows a day’s estimated currents with tracks of all drifters deployed in the area over the last months.

caption_original:
Have you ever wondered where the salmon in British Columbia’s hatcheries come from? First, we capture adult salmon to collect their milt and eggs, which are mixed together to fertilize and then placed in an aquarium to incubate. Once the eggs have hatched, the young salmon are fed in rearing ponds until they’re ready to be released into local streams. These practices allow our hatcheries to follow the natural life cycle of salmon while they work to improve low salmon stocks.  
Learn more about the Pacific salmon life-cycle here: http://ow.ly/wR1k30himnz

These practices allow our hatcheries to follow the natural life cycle of salmon while they work to improve low salmon stocks. Learn more about the Pacific salmon life-cycle here:

caption_original: We’re everywhere! In 2017, Fishery Officers in Central and Arctic Canada increased the time they spent patrolling Marine Protected Areas (MPA) by 350%. Using vessels, patrol planes, and helicopters, our officers travelled nearly 5,000 km in a 28-day span to ensure compliance in the Anguniaqvia niqiqyuam and Tarium Niryutait MPAs, as well as other areas of water. Learn more about a career as a fishery officer. http://ow.ly/X4hq30hin3i

We know that there’s nothing like hands-on learning to demonstrate the importance of salmon and the need to protect our local watersheds. That’s why we invited students from the Coldwater (Nc'łetkʷu) school in Merritt, British Columbia to participate in a coho salmon live-spawning tour. These young aquatic stewards learned about the salmon life-cycle while participating in an egg-take and incubation process. Learn more about our Stream to Sea education program here: 
http://ow.ly/sDGE30h02UY

caption_original:
The Tubenose Goby is a small, bottom-dwelling invasive fish that lives among the aquatic vegetation found in nearshore waters of lakes and rivers. Since its discovery in North America in the late 1980s, Tubenose Goby have been found in a few locations in the Great Lakes. To prevent the spread of this invasive species, never buy or use Tubenose Goby as bait, and never transfer live bait between waterbodies. It is against the law. Scientists are concerned about the possible long-term effects, because it can beat resident fish for habitat and food. This is a real concern for bottom-dwelling fishes, like Rainbow Darter and Northern Madtom.
For more information, or to report sightings, please visit http://ow.ly/KiLk30h9x2w

To prevent the spread of this invasive species, never buy or use Tubenose Goby as bait, and never transfer live bait between waterbodies. It is against the law. Scientists are concerned about the possible long-term effects, because it can beat resident fish for habitat and food. This is a real concern for bottom-dwelling fishes, like Rainbow Darter and Northern Madtom. For more information, or to report sightings, please visit

In the immediate future services to freshwater fishers especially in the North and Indigenous communities will continue uninterrupted. We’re working with stakeholders to determine the long term direction of the corporation.
